items.doc: Technical Code for Substation Layout Design
items.question: According to the current Technical Specifications for Substation Layout Design (e.g., GB 50058), substation road design must incorporate effective flood prevention and drainage measures, such as drainage ditches, rainwater pipes, and reservoirs, to ensure normal road access during rainy seasons or floods. Reinforcement measures must also be implemented where agricultural irrigation channels cross roads to prevent channel water overflow or erosion of the road surface.

According to DL/T 522-2021 Technical Specifications for Substation Layout Design, to prevent the spread of fire and casualties in the event of an accident involving oil-immersed transformers or combustible medium capacitors, fire separation distances shall be established, and the number and opening methods of surrounding doors and windows shall be restricted.

According to the Technical Code for Substation Layout Design, when constructing substations in mountainous or hilly regions, to reduce engineering costs and ensure slope stability, a stepped layout should be prioritised. Where feasible and subject to process requirements, large-scale earthworks (deep excavation and high filling) should be minimised.

According to GB 50073-2013 'Methods for Measuring Environmental Vibration in Urban Areas' and substation design codes, the fire separation distance for substation buildings (including control buildings, GIS buildings, etc.) shall be calculated based on the closest distance between the external walls of adjacent buildings. Where external walls feature protruding combustible components, the distance shall be measured from the outer edge of such projections.

According to the Technical Code for Substation Layout Design (inferred from the document title), when the relay room is located within the outdoor switchgear area, its clearance from the outdoor switchgear is entirely determined by the process discipline without reference to national or industry standards.

According to the Technical Code for Substation Layout Design (DL/T 522-2019), when the external walls of two adjacent buildings are both non-combustible materials, and neither wall has any door or window openings or exposed combustible eaves, the fire separation distance may be reduced by 25%.

According to DL/T 5056-2007 Technical Specifications for Engineering Design of 220kVâ€“500kV Substations, the minimum horizontal clearance between underground pipelines and buildings, structures, roads, or other pipelines represents the minimum requirement. In actual projects, adjustments may be made based on specific circumstances, provided they ensure safety, reliability, economic rationality, and compliance with relevant standards. Adjustments must be thoroughly justified and accompanied by appropriate safety measures.

According to current national standards such as the Technical Code for Substation Layout Design (inferred from the document name) and related specifications, the spacing between high-voltage power cables and control cables depends not only on process requirements but also requires comprehensive consideration of factors including cable voltage level, current-carrying capacity, insulation level, and operating environment to meet electromagnetic compatibility and safe operation requirements.

According to the Technical Regulations for Substation Layout Design, when constructing substations on collapsible loess or expansive soil sites, extensive greening should be restricted to ensure foundation stability and prevent differential settlement or heaving caused by soil moisture fluctuations.

According to the 'Technical Code for Substation Layout Design 37' and relevant power system standards, the rainwater pumping station should be located at the lowest point within the substation site. This facilitates the natural flow of rainwater into the pumping station, thereby reducing construction costs and complexity.
